I might be one of the few people I know that don't like this game that much.Every other list of "best Resident Evil games" will have RE2R ranked very close to the top, if not in the first place, and I totally disagree, really. RE3R rightfully receives a lot of critics for cutting a lot of content from the OG RE3: Nemesis, but I barely hear people complaining about the fact that RE2R cut almost all the differences the original game had between a playthrough A and B. 

The TLDR review is: Resident Evil 2 (1998) is better. Much better. I would recommend playing the original versions of RE2 and RE3 before (or even instead of) the remakes. You can find them on GOG for a fair price. But I understand most people nowadays may not be inclined to deal with tank controls and PS1 graphics, and, if you are one of those, just enjoy RE2R and RE3R for what they are. 

From now on, the review will have SPOILERS:

In RE2, you run through scenario A with Claire or Leon and then you go through scenario B with the other character (the canon way is Claire A, Leon B by the way). In the 1998 game this will lead you to different boss encounters during each run. 

G-Creature, for example, is always the first boss for scenario A, no matter wich character you chose, and that boss fight is not reutilized in scenario B. The same goes for the giant crocodile: it is the second boss for scenario A, but doesn't appear in scenario B. The final boss fight for scenario A is always the 4th form of Birkin (which is also exclusive to scenario A). In scenario B, the first boss will always be the 1st form of Birkin, you'll have to deal with Mr. X and the final boss is the 5th form of Birkin. All of those encounters exclusive to scenario B.

You can see they made an effort to distinguish scenario A and B. Not only the characters have exclusive weapons, but they also interact with different characters throughout the campaign and have to beat different bosses. By the other hand, in RE2R you'll deal with some bosses in your scenario A and then you'll have to beat the exact same bossfight (same arena, same everything) in scenario B. This happens for the first, second and third encounter with Birkin. It's mind-boggling, really. I cannot believe this game is praised as much as it is when it is a clear downgrade from the original in some aspects. The most outrageous change in my opinion is that Mr. X now appears in both scenarios, and that was a BIG difference in the OG where he just appears in scenario B. It really made that B run feel special.

To be honest, I don't really care that much about the story in RE games... that's not exactly why we like Capcom games, so I would be a little more inclined to ignore these incoherencies in the narrative if the gameplay was good enough, but I don't think it is. I think the atmosphere in RE2R is just fantastic through and through, but from all the over the shoulder games in the numbered series (with Revelations included) that's probably the worst the combat ever felt, no joke, I HATE the combat in this game. Guns feel very underpowered and even if the dismemberment is the best in the franchise (better than RE3R or even RE4R btw), I did not enjoy encountering zombies in this one. The RNG is through the roof, I bet you the original game from 1998 had more reliable patterns than the remake.

I remember entering the cafeteria near the reception of NEST in my first playthrough (on normal difficulty) and putting 7 bullets to the forehead of a zombie for him to finally fall, and I got so pissed I had to load the save to try it again. It took me 1 shot with the exact same weapon, and the zombie's head exploded. My average experience was much more akin to the first encounter with that zombie: a bunch of bullets and nothing happens. Maybe I'm the unluckiest guy in the world with RE2R RNG, that would explain why people love it so much while I would rather replay RE3R any day of the week than it, and it did not get better when I decided to replay the game earlier this year to get all the achievements (and I got them all, by the way). I genuinely think the combat in this game is worse than it was in the original game, so the only thing that was actually improved were the graphics.

I would still recommend, I guess... being one of the worst games in a franchise where most games are GOATed is not exactly the end of the world, but I actually think RE2R is as "bad" as RE6, if not worse. At least in RE6 you can play with some friend and still have some silly fun.

I played as Claire. The game eases you in quickly without really any tutorial needed. Good for immersion. There's very little on the UI to take away from that either. The camera angles are well done and I think they did well to copy that same terror from the original Resident Evil mansion. Hallways are narrow, dark and plenty of windows that can be broken into from outside keep you on your feet.

Pacing is good. While there is a sense of urgency to progress the story, I didn't feel rushed playing this game. I took my time to clear out each room and love that there is a color indicator to tell you when a room is cleared or still something you're missing. I only had to consult a guide once for something. This is a huge quality of life feature in the game and without it a lot of other survival horror games miss the point and have you backtracking for days figuring out what you missed.

The gunplay is satisfying. It'll take more than one headshot to kill most zombies. At times you're better off just running away and saving your ammo. It's a game of resource management and wits. There's not enough ammo here to go crazy like in CoD zombies. You have to be methodical about it but still fairly generous amount of ammo if you rather go in guns blazing.

I have to admit the story really engaged me. As with typical RE games you learn more from reading documents and letters as you progress through different areas. It's like you're a detective piecing together evidence and written testimonials to form a picture of what transpired.

Puzzles are well done. All of them were quite straight forward. The way the game is designed you can't progress without having solved the important ones so there's incentive to go through every area to find what you need to complete the next puzzle.

Resident Evil 2 is a remake of a game from 1998, but with this modern version, you wouldn’t be able to tell. This game set a standard back when it originally released, and still does. It’s accessible whether you’ve played no horror games ever, or every other Resident Evil game. It’s tense, punchy, and well-paced. Everything the game does is well done, and what it doesn’t do well, it doesn’t do. It is exactly what it sets out to be; the most refined 3rd-person survival horror game, benchmark for the genre, and a modern representation of a legendary game.
I don’t think it’s long enough to justify it’s $60 pricetag, but it does come with RE3 and a Dead by Daylight clone named Resident Evil Resistance that I would not recommend you play. I would recommend RE3 though, despite it’s odd legacy. It regularly goes on sale for $10-$15 dollars.

This is how you do a TRUE remake. What Capcom did here with RE2 is nothing short of amazing. They took one of the franchise's most beloved classical entries and brought it into the modern era as a polished third person over-the-shoulder survival horror game. If you played the original, the game truly captures the feel of the initial release while still feeling fresh and new. The additional character vignettes for characters like Robert Kendo are also done very well and ass to the overall experience. Of course, the Fourth Survivor with HUNK is an obvious high point as well. I previously 100% this game on console and am enjoying going through it again. Definitely worth getting whether you played the original or not.

Resident Evil 2 Remake is an absolutely amazing experience from start to finish. The story is incredible, the characters are memorable, and the atmosphere is masterfully crafted. The soundtrack is impeccable, at times nostalgic, at others intensely immersive.

Playing as Leon and Claire feels fantastic, and while their campaigns share many similarities, the minor differences in dialogue, encounters, and certain fights keep each playthrough fresh. The game’s gore, sound design, and overall tension are phenomenal, with a constant sense of suspense that really pulls you in.

The game can feel punishing with its ammunition, but in my experience, that only made things better. It forces you to think strategically and use your resources wisely, which adds to the survival-horror feel.

There are a few story moments that I think could have been explained better, and I would have liked to see more content carried over from the original. Even so, these are minor issues in an otherwise outstanding remake.

Overall, I absolutely love this game. It’s a masterpiece and a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike.

Resident Evil 2 RE:make is an incredible love letter to the original Resident Evil 2 from 1998. This game has a fair amount of replay value that doesn't feel artificial, as I have manually chose on my own accord that I want to replay THIS remake on several occasions. Leon and Claire's characters were given a bit more personality that I am honestly a fan of. This game doesn't stiff us on any extra content either we are given A & B scenarios (more on that later). We get the Fourth Survivor Hunk minigame, along the Tofu reskins, which I am surprised we got, and we got a "what-if" gamemode with the Ghost Suriviors. Which is a fair amount of content for a $60, but I probably would still settle for a cheaper price tag as the game is nearly six years old now (as of writing). But hey, it's still worth a helluva lot more than my ex-wife.

Mr. X has gotten a huge upgrade in this game, he has been transformed to a relatively consistent looming threat in both scenarios. He is no longer restricted to scripted events that would basically end as you change loading zones. The heavy footsteps you hear in the RPD is genuinely freaky, and sometimes encountering him can force you to reroute which is awesome. Chief Irons is painted to be a massive [CENSORED] and a [CENSORED] in the RE:make. Which is in my opinion better than his original appearance, because screw that guy. Ada is fun, the rest of the side characters don't deviate much from the original material so that is good.

I did mention not everything is perfect about this experience. And most of that boils down to how certain things in this RE:make versus the 1998 release. My main two gripes are the beginning voyage to the RPD, and the A&B scenario system. In the 1998 release, the player is required to outrun hoards of zombies to make it to the RPD, with a lot of content and environments to explore before even arriving to the game's main set-piece. The "voyage" in the RE:make is following a linear path that doesn't deviate and doesn't have different affecting outcomes depending on which routes you take. Which is very similar to the arguments with my ex-wife, no matter what approach I took, it would still lead to the same hellish outcomes. Even worse, the B scenario doesn't have that voyage at all, you start within the confines within the RPD. This linear routing does have some effects inside the RPD; however, it is much more tame and I will not dock it there. The second issue being that the A & B scenarios don't carry weight on each other in the RE:make. It's kind of hard to explain, but the original worked on two disks. One for the A scenario, and one for the B scenario. Some of the items you took from A scenario would directly affect the player when playing the B scenario, as they wouldn't be there. That doesn't exist here, it is a similar story where the beats all still hit, just at different points. But again, the pros of this RE:make are much greater than the cons.

All in all, Resident Evil 2 RE:make is an experience I can recommend to both new and original players. And in most situations I would probably recommend the RE:make over the original, and they can play the original afterwards if it interests them. RE2make presents fewer, but still equally fun puzzles and games within it's confines, unlike my ex-wife as she dealt in a greater amount manipulative games which are not very fun. Thought I give it a try since it was on sale but boy was that a mistake. I have yet to find a game as nonsensical as this one. A police station with a built in escape route predicated on solving a medeival puzzle. Also Sorry Chris, you can’t get your gun until you solve this Victorian Royalty Exhibit Puzzle Box. 

The Raccoon City Police Station is, frankly, a spatial joke: a police headquarters that functions like a gothic puzzle dungeon where basic movement is impossible without jewels, crests, relief plates, and medieval mechanisms. It asks you to believe trained police officers conducted daily operations in a building where half the rooms are locked by Renaissance escape-room gimmicks. 

The environment feels like a curated obstacle course rather than a lived-in space, the threat feels constructed instead of emergent. The world feels like a themed attraction, not an actual place undergoing catastrophe.

The game’s reliance on arbitrary locks, jewels, and levers to gate progression interrupts narrative flow, constantly reminding reminding you that you're navigating a game rather than surviving in a coherent world.  Those arbitrary obstacles scream “game mechanics first, story second.” You aren’t surviving; you're solving designer-imposed riddles. Such BS can work for fast paced shooters like Doom (Green card to yellow to red), not a horror STORY, that predicates on worldbuilding, characters and motivations to create stakes and TENSION.

Leon and Claire are but thin sketches, their personalities conveyed more through posture and archetype than meaningful interaction. Supporting characters like Sherry, Ada, and Annette are motivationally inconsistent, shifting behaviors to suit cutscene tension rather than psychological continuity.

The tension built by the setting collapses under the weight of these mechanical contrivances, and no amount of moody lighting or zombie groans can mask the cognitive dissonance. RE2 struggles not because it lacks atmosphere, but because it consistently sabotages the very immersion it demands.

Basically it's a contrived rat maze that you're being pushed through, making "the plot" happen. Shut off your brain or forget about any immersion and just slog it till the end, like I did. The problem is, once you get past the atmosphere, the game design starts fighting you. Zombies take half a magazine to kill, and even then, they might “wake up” later because of the game’s cold-spawn system. You’re punished for engaging zombies in a zombie game.

Exploration, one of the series’ best traits, becomes a chore. The RPD is basically a maze of same-looking corridors and offices that all blur together after a while. Most rooms exist only to host a single key item or puzzle piece, then never matter again. There’s no sense of discovery — just checklist progression. Worse, Mr. X and the respawning zombies turn exploration into stress management instead of curiosity. You’re not exploring because you want to, you’re just trying to survive long enough to grab the next key. Compare that to RE4R, where every area feels handcrafted — treasure, secrets, combat routes, new enemies — the map itself rewards you for looking around. In RE2R, it’s just find item, unlock door, repeat.

Combat is almost entirely unrewarding. Killing enemies drains scarce ammo and gives you nothing in return. Compare that with RE4 Remake’s elegant loop of fight -> loot -> upgrade — RE2 Remake just leaves you weaker after every encounter so It encourages speedrunning instead of exploration, which is bad, boring design.

Technically, it’s polished, and the atmosphere is strong. But as a game, it’s shallow. The enemy roster is tiny — zombies, lickers, sewer monsters, plant zombies —that's all XD. The campaign feels more like a museum tour of 1998 than a modern survival-horror experience.
